text.p: Strawberries and cream, Pimms and ... queuing.
It was business as usual on Monday for the start of the 111th Wimbledon championships -- a familiar line weaved its way around the streets and parks of the leafy London suburb.
But the British, like no other nationality, are patient and Frances Burgess, 37, of Oxford, is this year's champion after a marathon 66-hour wait.
She pitched her igloo tent on the footpath at the main entrance to the courts at 8pm on Friday to ensure she could get a seat for the opening of court one at 1.30pm on Monday.
By the time local favourite Tim Henman and Canada's Daniel Nestor inaugurated the court, she had endured numerous thunderstorms, but the long vigil was worth it.

"This is my 12th year I've lined-up here, but usually I'd only come on the Saturday," said Burgess, a groom on a thoroughbred stud farm. "But I wanted to make sure I could get tickets for court one -- you could call me a tennis addict."
By midday on Saturday, the footpath resembled a camping ground with 20 tents lined up and by the early hours of Monday the number of people had swelled to thousands.
That meant hundreds missed out as there were only 500 unreserved seats in the new 11,000-seat number one court.
